title: A Case Series of the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) in Three Febrile Infants in New York.
text: A Case Series of the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) in Three Febrile Infants in New York.

similar.title: SARS-CoV-2 infection (COVID-19) in febrile infants without respiratory distress.
text: SARS-CoV-2 infection (COVID-19) in febrile infants without respiratory distress.

We report two cases of SARS-CoV-2 infection (COVID-19) in infants presenting with fever in the absence of respiratory distress who required hospitalization for evaluation of possible invasive bacterial infections. The diagnoses resulted from routine isolation and real-time RT-PCR-based testing for SARS-CoV-2 for febrile infants in an outbreak setting.
abstract: We report two cases of SARS-CoV-2 infection (COVID-19) in infants presenting with fever in the absence of respiratory distress who required hospitalization for evaluation of possible invasive bacterial infections. The diagnoses resulted from routine isolation and real-time RT-PCR-based testing for SARS-CoV-2 for febrile infants in an outbreak setting.

similar.title: Febrile Infant: COVID-19 in Addition to the Usual Suspects.
text: Febrile Infant: COVID-19 in Addition to the Usual Suspects.

similar.title: SARS-CoV-2 infection presenting as a febrile rash.
text: SARS-CoV-2 infection presenting as a febrile rash.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared that Coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) is a public health emergency of international concern as it continues to spread worldwide.(1) After a median incubation period of 4 days, fever and cough are the two most common manifestations of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection.

similar.title: CORONAVIRUS DISEASE 2019 IN NEWBORNS AND VERY YOUNG INFANTS: A SERIES OF SIX PATIENTS IN FRANCE.
text: CORONAVIRUS DISEASE 2019 IN NEWBORNS AND VERY YOUNG INFANTS: A SERIES OF SIX PATIENTS IN FRANCE.

We present here a series of 6 infants hospitalized for coronavirus disease 2019 infection from March 14 to March 30, 5 of them are newborns. All 6 patients presented with fever, it was the main symptom for all of them. Only one of them needed oxygen; the others were hospitalized for surveillance but did not need specific care. In our series, coronavirus disease 2019 infection is mostly mild in neonates.
abstract: We present here a series of 6 infants hospitalized for coronavirus disease 2019 infection from March 14 to March 30, 5 of them are newborns. All 6 patients presented with fever, it was the main symptom for all of them. Only one of them needed oxygen; the others were hospitalized for surveillance but did not need specific care. In our series, coronavirus disease 2019 infection is mostly mild in neonates.
